w:r.w:t: Important Recommendation: Refer to these Standards by Version as well as Name.
to present the standard outputs that should be produced to document software engineering products. These sta
Ensure that all audiences have the outputs
containing the information they need to efficiently do their jobs.
Ensure that, as documentation is stored in standard formats and in standard places, it is easy to find and understand.
Ensure that there is resilience in supporting our software products by encouraging knowledge retention.
Ensure that time is not wasted producing outputs where the benefit is unlikely to exceed the cost.
Remember, that the cost of documentation is not only its initial creation
it must also be maintained. A document that is significantly out of
These standards are based on what Software Engineering documentation art
ts have actually been found useful in practice.
Important Recommendation: Refer to these Standards by Version as well as Name.
These standards are likely to be updated on an ongoing basis. Anything using these standards should therefore refer to these standards not only be name (“
”). It should not be assumed that established products will be continually
updated to always reflect the very latest iteration of these standards: therefore recording which
ceding versions of these standards) is essential.
The readme should be in markdown format.
should be in a Word compatible or markdown format, as is appropriate for their complexity.

here Word formats are used open and textual (rather than binary) formats are to be preferred, to better ensure interoperability with other word processing tools, and to better enable file comparisons and merges using non-Word specific tools (such exercises are likely to be challenging given the complexity of even the textual formats, but will be effectively impossible if binary formats are used).
Any diagrams appearing in documents must be stored along with
the document in an editable format.
Some documentation outputs may be created automatically by tools
supporting the design of relational data models also support the exporting of entity-relationship diagram and the creation
of accompanying documentation, and the Java

Javadoc tool and standard. In these cases we are obviously limited to the formats supported by the tool, but the same principles apply: where the tool allows a choice of formats open or widely used formats are to be preferred to anything closed and proprietary, and for textual content textual based formats (e.g.
) are to be preferred over binary formats.
should be co-located with the code in the git repository for the
product. Sometimes, however, that might not be possible, for example because of security considerations. In all cases though (see
) the git repository should include information explaining where to find all the
All documents should include a version number. The version number should be a number including up to two decimal pl
ces, e.g. 1.2 or 1.2.3, where a change in the leftmost digit will represent the most significant revision, and a change in the rightmost digit the most minor.
Until a given versioned document has passed a review, i.e. while it is still draft, a letter should be appended to the version number to indicate the current draft, e.g. 1.2.3 Draft B.
In the preceding example note that, while version 1.2.3 Draft B was still under review, it would
be acceptable for the previous non draft,
version of the document, i.e. version 1.2.2, to still be in use.
These are simply the documents containing the
The typical standard readme that is stored within a software product’s usually git repository. It should provide a very brief outline introduction to the product and act as a
” linking to or explaining where to find other important items, especially the other standard documentation outputs.
If a product is reasonably simple it is possible that one or other of the other standard products below, particularly the deve
oper’s guide, may also be incorporated as part of the readme, though, if this has been done, that section of the readme should be so entitled (e.g. as the “Deve
oper’s Guide”) so that the inclusion of that document in the readme is clear and explicit.
The audience for this document will mainly be developers new to the product and anyone seeking to reuse the software product or parts of the software product in any way.
The document describing the high level
, and recording all the technical standards and main design patterns adopted
It may dip into more detail on particul
It is likely to include diagrams, often in Universal Modelling
, such as realisations of any significant user stories or use cases.

In particular the Application Architecture must describe any interfaces, interactions or inter-dependencies with other systems, so that how a given application fits into the “big picture” of an “ecosystem” of application
Such knowledge can often be critical for analysing the impacts of proposed changes or for operational support.
It will include or “link to” any formal API definitions.
The audience for this document will be those seeking a broad technical overview of the product, such as deve
opers new to working on the product or architects or other
seeking to integrate with the product to re-use the product in whole or in part, or even just as an exemplar, or
The document may also serve as a “bridge” helping to explain to business analysts and to architects respectively how their requi
use cases and architectural concepts are being implemented in practice.
For particularly complex areas of the application, the document may even serve as an aide memoir to the current
At least a high level data model should be captured for all products. Where this is simple a conceptual model in the Application Architecture is likely to be sufficient
, though there is no point repeating work if such a model is already available, for example if it has already been produced by the Solution Architects.
here a software product uses complex data structures, e.g. a large relational data model, consideration should be given to
data model itself. It is recommended that rather than attempting to document such a data model purely by “hand”
(e.g. perhaps by describing tables in Word)

, appropriate data modelling tools are adopted that either generate documentation directly from either an already built model or, in the cases where the data modelling tool is itself used to build the model, allow the model to be documented as the model itself is being designed within the tool.
se should also be made of any documentation features supported by the database technology adopted, e.g.
The audience for such data documents is likely to comprise of developers
(to facilitate understanding of how to use the model)
, data architects (e.g. to explain how any data architecture standards have been adopted)
business analysts (e.g. to explain how any business concepts are actually being modelled)
and data analysts who are seeking to use the data in further reports and analyses.
(Data documentation can therefore be an important aspect of making our data more useful by making it more shareable).
This is a “getting started and keeping going” guide for deve
opers working on the software product. It should explain everything from

what training or experience, kit and software a new developer will need, through how to get the latest source code (including an explanation of the structure of the repository if its complex), how to build an individual development environment, what tools are used, how to access any shared development or test environments and standard
and best practises for working on the product, up to and including doing a live release.
Where there are areas of particular complexity additional documents may exist as supplements to this guide.
Though, of course, the security implications of each and every document should be assessed when considering wh
ere it is stored, the Developer
Guide is likely to be among the most sensitive documents, and therefore
the least appropriate document to store in a public repository.

ly to be exclusively developers, especially developers new to the project, but also as an “aide memoir” and source of task-based checklists for developers already working on a project. On a day to day basis, this is likely to be the most likely useful document for the developers themselves.
It is also the “emergency rip cord” providing sufficient assurance that key developer knowledge related to how to work on a software product can never be entirely lost.
Following the guidance that the code itself should be as clear as possible, these should generally describe the “what and why” and not the “how”. Beyond this general principle, spe
guidance should be provided by the standards for the spe

Again this will be technology dependent but, as discussed above with regard to data models, it is recommended that such approaches are used where-ever feasible, as this can provide an efficient way to produce accurate documentation and keep it up to date. More detail should be provided in coding and tools standards.
documentation can never, however, do the job entirely on its own.
automatically generated “skeleton”. Additionally some keys documents, such as the Developer’s
uide, are not capable of auto
As noted above, if data repository/database technologies support explanatory “metadata” and/or “comments” within the data structures themselves,
we should make use of such capabilities, especially where tools are also available that can automatically include this information in any
Where a software product includes an API for use by other

, i.e. where it is acting as a shareable component or service in any way, that formal API must be documented according to the relevant technology specific standards. For example, a Java library intended for re-use in other applications
include the appropriate Javadoc, and a SOAP web service should publish i

WSDL. Where there is a facility for publishing API definitions in a form that can be read by other tools to automatically create “client” components, then those API definitions should be made available in at least that format.
Any such API definitions should either be included in the Application Architecture document or “linked to” from the Application Architecture document.

User documentation will normally be at output of business analysis, content design or the lead users, or any or all of the above working together. However, the need for and specific form of user documentation may influence software design: for example, should online help or tool tips be available as part of the software product? The succ
ess of the software product may
critically depend on whether such documentation is made available.
Software Engineering may therefore need to provide a mechanism for making user documentation accessible, but is should be noted that
, including the standards which that content follows,

xsd:annotation.xsd:documentation: This value indicates the number of saves or revisions. The application is responsible for updating this value after each revision.
